text: Teach me to find clients that will pay over 4K for an article. :astonished:

elements.text: Teach me to find clients that will pay over 4K for an article.

text:
I think it’s the exception to the rule haha. There are a few factors that made this align the way it did:

1. We used to be *direct competitors* so I’m uniquely positioned to know his market and know how a business owner in his position would think. This enables me to know his business model so well that he can trust me to write content for him that’s completely turnkey so he doesn’t have to worry about reviewing it for quality or direction.
2. His LTV is ≈$500K so a single article can easily provide an insane ROI.
Essentially, it gives him the two most important things that influence what someone is willing to pay for something: time and value.

so I’m uniquely positioned to know his market and know how a business owner in his position would think. This enables me to know his business model so well that he can trust me to write content for him that’s completely turnkey so he doesn’t have to worry about reviewing it for quality or direction.
His LTV is ≈$500K so a single article can easily provide an insane ROI.

text:
The best way to charge more and work less is to have a mindset/identity change. You’ll first have to focus on the value you provide for your clients, as Skyler mentioned above.       

Then it is also important how you position yourself and what type of clients you work for. How does your content translate into revenue? Are you positioned as a conversion copywriter, SEO optimized content service, or something else that can make you stand out? Are the clients startups (lower budgets) or established companies that generate 7/8 figures in annual revenue? (They can afford more). 

Most importantly, what’s your preferred lifestyle? Your work should help support your preferred lifestyle, not your work to dictate what your lifestyle can be. Many successful” people end up in this trap where they end up in a high paying position, yet they have no control over their time. 

Personally, for me, success is spending time with my family and practicing hobbies on my terms. Time is your most important commodity, so use it wisely. 

I also recommend journaling and meditation, which will help with your mindset change.

elements.text:
The best way to charge more and work less is to have a mindset/identity change. You’ll first have to focus on the value you provide for your clients, as Skyler mentioned above.       

Then it is also important how you position yourself and what type of clients you work for. How does your content translate into revenue? Are you positioned as a conversion copywriter, SEO optimized content service, or something else that can make you stand out? Are the clients startups (lower budgets) or established companies that generate 7/8 figures in annual revenue? (They can afford more). 

Most importantly, what’s your preferred lifestyle? Your work should help support your preferred lifestyle, not your work to dictate what your lifestyle can be. Many successful” people end up in this trap where they end up in a high paying position, yet they have no control over their time. 

Personally, for me, success is spending time with my family and practicing hobbies on my terms. Time is your most important commodity, so use it wisely. 

I also recommend journaling and meditation, which will help with your mindset change.

text: I’ll also add that I wouldn’t do this for most other companies. My time is consumed enough as it is running my own business and developing software. Writing for my former competitor is like a cathartic release — enabling me to vent about the problems I saw in the market and industry he services and be extremely contrarian, which, like <@U016NBFS16Y> mentioned, makes it worth it from a lifestyle perspective.
